articles.title: Oxlint: A New JS Linter '50-100x Faster' than ESLint?
articles.description: Making tools as fast as possible is a common theme in the JavaScript world, and it's the MO for the JavaScript Oxidation Compiler toolkit. Oxlint is one of their tools that‚Äôs now GA. It's still early days, but when Evan You says ‚Äúthe performance is absolutely nuts‚Äù when running against the Vue 3 codebase, we sit up and listen.
articles.author: Boshen

articles.title: Bun v1.0.18: The JS Runtime Preparing to Take Over the World
articles.description: I might have overegged the headline, but Bun is on a serious mission to replace Node.js, at least, with their 'one goal for 2024' being to ‚Äúflip the default backend JavaScript runtime from Node.js to Bun.‚Äù They are also placing a focus on shipping Windows support ASAP.
articles.author: Jarred Sumner et al.

articles.title: Visual Studio Code November 2023
articles.description: The latest VS Code release has some handy enhancements for JS developers, including a V8 heap snapshot visualizer, the ability to drag tabs into their own new windows (a.k.a. ‚Äòfloating editor windows‚Äô), and TypeScript 5.3.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: Deno 1.39: The Return of WebGPU
articles.description: Deno introduced WebGPU support in Deno 1.8 but it was removed for various reasons. It‚Äôs back and gives you a tidy way to work with the GPU directly from JavaScript (behind the --unstable-webgpu flag, at least). Improvements to Node.js compatibility and various Deno APIs, as well as TypeScript 5.3, are included.
articles.author: The Deno Team

articles.title: The Await Event Horizon in JavaScript
articles.description: You know someone‚Äôs getting heavy when they start a JavaScript article by talking about the event horizon around black holes and how ‚Äúa similar boundary exists around every JavaScript Promise.‚Äù Enjoy.
articles.author: Charles Lowell

articles.title: Benchmarking, Profiling, and Optimizing JS Libraries
articles.description: As part of this year‚Äôs Web Performance Calendar, take a journey with St√©phane to learn about optimizing a library (globalize, in his case) by way of benchmarking and profiling.
articles.author: St√©phane Goetz

articles.title: The New TC39 FAQs
articles.description: TC39 is the committee responsible for evolving and maintaining the ECMAScript spec, the standardized form of JavaScript, and its members have started a disclaimer-riddled FAQ. You can suggest new topics by opening an issue, or learn a little from the nine questions covered so far, including Will JS ever add JSX notation? and Will WebAssembly replace JS?
articles.author: Ecma TC39

articles.title: You Don't Need JavaScript for That
articles.description: ‚ÄúJust because you know something needs JavaScript, doesn‚Äôt mean it still does. You can make better websites if you test those assumptions every now and then.‚Äù
articles.author: Killian Valkhof

articles.title: What Vue‚Äôs Creator Learned the Hard Way with Vue 3
articles.description: Evan You shared some of the lessons he learned from the release and reception of Vue 3 around things like including a lot of small breaking changes, to choosing deprecation over breaking changes.
articles.author: Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Deploying Node.js with Google's Duet AI
articles.description: Duet AI is Google‚Äôs AI-based assistive agent that works both in the IDE and within Google Cloud.
articles.author: Google Cloud

articles.title: RE:DOM 4.0: The 2K UI Library
articles.description: We first linked to this library over 6 years ago but it‚Äôs still going, so if you want something to help with creating and syncing DOM elements that‚Äôs ‚Äòclose to the metal‚Äô, it‚Äôs worth a look. v4.0 enables tree shaking and adds viewFactory.
articles.author: Juha Lindstedt and contributors

articles.title: TS Docs: Online Reference Docs for npm Packages
articles.description: Browse reference TypeScript documentation for any package or version of a library.
articles.author: Shubham Kanodia

articles.title: Seroval 1.0: Stringify JS Values
articles.description: A handy utility library for turning JavaScript values into strings that can handle far more complex things than JSON, say.
articles.author: Alexis H. Munsayac

articles.title: SpaceTime 7.5: A Lightweight Timezone Library
articles.description: Use this to calculate times in other timezones. Has a Moment-like API but is immutable. No dependencies. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Spencer Kelly

articles.title: React Responsive Pagination: Component for Smart Pagination
articles.description: A responsive pagination component which intelligently adjusts to the available width. The homepage is a live demo, or you can hit the GitHub repo.
articles.author: Jon Elantha

articles.title: Svelte SPA Router: A Router for Svelte 3 and 4 SPAs
articles.description: Previously for Svelte 3 only, Svelte 4 support has now been added. Upgrade guide.
articles.author: Alessandro (Ale) Segala

articles.title: üìä vue-chartjs: A Vue.js Wrapper for Chart.js
articles.description: Using Vue? Want charts? Consider this. Demos here.
articles.author: Jakub

articles.title: Three.js Procedural Planets
articles.description: This is gorgeous! You can have a lot of fun adjusting the parameters to change the outcome, or you can spin up and play with your own copy using the source code. If you don‚Äôt want to stress out your browser, you can see how it looks ‚ñ∂Ô∏è in this video.
articles.author: Daniel Greenheck

articles.description: üéÅ GitHub Unwrapped is a fun project that renders your GitHub activity into a video (a la Spotify's "Wrapped" roundups). The source is available. It uses the React-based Remotion to dynamically create the videos.
Safari 17.2 is a particularly jam-packed release of Apple's browser, but on the JavaScript side it has added support for import attributes.
There's only a day or two left to take the State of JS 2023 survey.
The latest Storybook beta has added support for React Server Components.
A handy list of JavaScript engines, runtimes, and interpreters.
Million 3.0 ‚Äì VDOM replacement for faster React.
Croner 8.0 ‚Äì Trigger functions using cron syntax.
Rollup 4.9, Ember.js 5.5, Expo Router 3.0 beta, Remix 2.4.

articles.title: CSS Wrapped: 2023
articles.description: 2023 was truly a huge year for all things CSS. This detailed post from the Chrome teams brings together all of the headline features that landed in Chrome and across the web platform this year, including nesting, new color functions, the :has selector, linear-easing, and much much more. There‚Äôs been so much added to our CSS tool belt this year, that this recap may prove handy in reminding us all what we can now actually do.
articles.author: Chrome for Developers

articles.title: WebKit Features in Safari 17.2
articles.description: The WebKit team are closing out the year with a sizeable release of Safari, packing in 39 new features and over 150 various fixes. Notable additions include richer CSS nesting support, new math functions, support for preloading responsive images, new sizing units ‚Äî including the likes of cap, ch, and ex. Lots to dig into here.
articles.author: Jen Simmons and Marcos C√°ceres (WebKit)

articles.title: You Don't Need JavaScript for That
articles.description: Killian notes that a core principle of web development is choosing the least powerful language suitable for a given purpose. In practice this means preferring HTML over CSS, and then CSS over JS.
articles.author: Killian Valkhof

articles.title: HTML5 Boilerplate v9.0.0 Released
articles.description: A bit of a blast from the past! This popular frontend template (with over 50k stars on GitHub) was last updated over three years ago, but is back with a flurry of sensible changes. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Rob Larsen

articles.title: Preparing For Interaction To Next Paint, A New Web Core Vital
articles.description: Starting in March, ‚ÄòInteraction to Next Paint‚Äô will formally replace ‚ÄòFirst Input Delay‚Äô as a Core Web Vital metric. Here‚Äôs how the two metrics differ, why we needed a new way to measure interaction responsiveness, and how you can start optimizing the performance of your site for a seamless transition to this new metric.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: An Interactive Guide to SVG Loading Spinners
articles.description: Lots of good visuals and code examples here showing us, step-by-step, how to create neat looking SVG loading spinners (using attributes like stroke-dasharray and stroke-dashoffset).
articles.author: S√©bastien No√´l

articles.title: How to Use Responsive HTML Video (...and Audio)
articles.description: The responsive video standard now works across all major browsers.
articles.author: Scott Jehl

articles.title: Lost in Translation: Tips for Multilingual Web Accessibility
articles.description: Some practical tips for navigating the intersection between web accessibility and internationalization/localization.
articles.author: Ben Myers

articles.title: How to Use Chrome's 'Accessibility Tree'
articles.description: A look at what the accessibility tree is, how to access it, and how to use its information.
articles.author: Whitney Lewis

articles.title: How I Brought My LCP Down to Under 350 ms for Google-Referred Users
articles.description: An exploration of the techniques used to optimize performance on a high-traffic website.
articles.author: Pawe≈Ç Pokrywka

articles.title: Epic Easing: An Interactive Tool to Generate Custom Easing Functions
articles.description: A fun way to mess around with and learn easing functions, with lots of pre-built examples. The tool also lets you export as CSS, SCSS, Swift, and even Objective-C.
articles.author: Meritt Thomas

articles.title: AutoAnimate: Add Motion to Your Apps with a Single Line of Code
articles.description: You can view some nice examples on the page and this can be used with React, Vue, Svelte, or just plain JavaScript.
articles.author: FormKit

articles.title: Clamp Calculator: Generate Custom CSS for Fluid Typography Using clamp()
articles.description: A helper for fluid type in responsive designs that allows you to generate any number of custom properties using CSS‚Äôs clamp() function, representing fluid type tokens you can drop into a project.
articles.author: James Gilyead and Trys Mudford

articles.title: UserStock: Free Photos of People's Faces to Use as Avatars in Mockups and Prototypes
articles.description: Includes drop-downs to filter using one of five different age groups and/or image style, but most importantly: these are not AI-generated images.
articles.author: UserStock

articles.title: SVGO 3.1: A Node.js-Powered SVG Optimizer
articles.description: If you‚Äôve worked with SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) at all, you‚Äôve probably seen they can be filled with all sorts of junk code.. SVGO to the rescue.
articles.author: Kir Belevich

articles.title: Color Lisa: A Curated List of Color Palettes Based on¬†Masterpieces
articles.description: A unique way to get some color inspiration from those who've used color best. Scroll alphabetically through artist names and view a hex-based color palette for that artist‚Äôs most famous piece of work.
articles.author: RYAN MCGUIRE

articles.title: Keep React: A Library of 40+ Components Built with React and Tailwind
articles.description: View all the components in the docs here, where you‚Äôll find lots of interactive demos.
articles.author: StaticMania
